dialogues.speaker: INT. SHOP. NR CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAWN.
dialogues.text: The HUM of a large refrigerator just audible over the sound of Indian music - MARGARET, briefly glimpsed pondering cartons of milk. The electronic PEEP of the cash til. A man on a mobile phone pushes past MARGARET, who takes her place second in the queue. The female shopkeeper piles newspapers on the counter in front of MARGARET. Distracted by images of the bombed hotel on the TV, she hesitates for beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One forty-nine please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much is the milk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-nine pence. (taking the change) Thank you. MARGARET turns to leave, jostled by a tall young man wired into an ipod. EXT. STREET. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAWN. MARGARET heads down the busy street, shopping bag in hand. INT. KITCHEN. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY. MARGARET sits at breakfast with her husband DENIS, sipping tea. DENIS butters his toast. MARGARET shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too much. Much too much butter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like butter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milk's gone up. MARGARET reaches for a jug, pouring milk into it, sliding it down on a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49p a pint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good grief! We'll have to economise. I suppose we could always sell the car. (chuckles) Or take in paying guests!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scoops up the newspaper and glances towards the door -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch out. She's on the prowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET looks beyond DENIS to a a sense of growing commotion. A concerned POLICE GUARD coming up the stairs meeting JUNE [early 60's] MARGARET's carer, along a distant corridor, steady on the approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to DENIS) Eat your egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNE smiles with visible relief on seeing MARGARET, now sitting tapping open her egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodness! There you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNE's look of quiet concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET eats her egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But for JUNE, she is entirely alone. INT. CORRIDOR CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand how it happened, how could she possibly have got out? It's very very important -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET looks out of the kitchen. Her POV down the corridor of JUNE and the POLICEMAN and a CLEANER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please just make it really clear. Who's on after you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dixon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET slips away. INT.HALL. CHESTER SQUARE. DAY. MARGARET hurries through the hall. INT. BEDROOM. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT.DAY. A wide cupboard- MARGARET's eyes move back along the rail in front of her, her fingers touch hanger after hanger of brown tweed and grey twill. JUNE goes over to the curtains, pulling them back, letting in the sunlight-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful day. Oh, you've made a start. Carol's coming soon, I'll get some bags. Anything you want to go to Mark, I'll bring up a suitcase for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smell of smoke lingering. Suddenly DENIS' hand reaches across, wavering between jackets of brown tweed and grey twill- He reaches for a suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no no no. The grey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The swipe of a clothes brush, briefly seen, drawn across one sleeve-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Distant footsteps-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Definitely the grey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNE returns, oblivious-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Righty ho. Boss knows best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNE spies the newspaper, sees the photos of twisted carnage on the front page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let her take my paper away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNE reaches one hand out to scoop it up in passing-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I haven't had a chance to look at that yet, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNE hesitates, leaves the newspaper resting on the bed as she heads off with the suit on a hanger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atta-girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS smiles as he stands in the bathroom doorway, soaping his face with shaving cream- He hums to himself as he resumes shaving until-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET looks up, DENIS has nicked his chin-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blot it...Blot it..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns, sees JUNE, through the ajar door, standing in the corridor, looking back at her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A comfortable drawing room, filled with the photographs and memorabilia of a former political life. MARGARET stands by the window, half a dozen of DENIS' ties in her hand. Pulling back the net curtain, MARGARET peers out- Two POLICEMAN stand down below next to a Police BMW car. They are lost in conversation, pointing to the door, clearly concerned. One POLICE MAN nods to the other, a sense of the changing of the guard as he drives off in the BMW. SUDDENLY from behind-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look what you've done. Are they to keep the loonies out or you in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET eyes DENIS, looking at her with wry smile -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be off then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wear your scarf. There's a chill out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly looming over her and grinning down as if at the top of a tunnel SUSIE, MARGARET's personal secretary carrying a cardboard box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning Lady Thatcher. Are you alright ? (concerned) How are you feeling ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine, thank you Susie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just been reading about the bombings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Frightful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUSIE's mobile goes off.    She fumbles in her bag to switch it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the books for you to sign. I brought as many as I could find. Shall we go through your appointments?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET looks at her still nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We said we'd go through them today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET nods-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, dear. Today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The invitation has come from Downing Street for the unveiling of your portrait. I'll put it on the mantelpiece, and there's an invitation from Lord Armstrong for lunch on the first Friday of next month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The murmur of SUSIE's voice, a kind of white noise-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said no because you've got a concert that afternoon but if you'd like to..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....It looks like a very interesting programme.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET's listens, oddly distracted-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they playing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUSIE looks at her momentarily at a loss then scrabbles back through the diary-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they said Rogers and Hammerstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `SHALL WE DANCE' FROM `THE KING & I" SUDDENLY BREAKIN THROUGH AS IF FROM ANOTHER TIME CARRYING INTO.... INT. SADLER'S WELLS. LONDON. 1950. NIGHT. An orchestra in full flight- A programme for THE KING & I on a woman's lap. A man' hand reaches in and her hands slips into his. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY. Whilst SUSIE shuffles through the arrangements at the desk in the background, MARGARET stands at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silly man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET's gaze, seeing DENIS just visible in the street below. He looks up, smiles,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't got his scarf on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET throws DENIS a half wave. In return, he twirls his umbrella and does a couple of steps of a Chaplin walk for her benefit before passing the Postman who is shuffling through his letters as he approaches the front step, below. SUSIE looks on with quiet concern. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY. MARGARET' is at her desk signing a stack of her memoirs, The Downing Street Years. MARGARET opens one, reaching for a pen. The curve of inky handwriting as she begins to sign them, Margaret Thatcher. Close on the swoop of the pen. Without missing a beat, she writes the name Margaret Roberts... The insistent blare of an air raid siren from another time cuts through - INT. BACK PARLOUR. SHOP. GRANTHAM. 1943. DUSK. The rumble of an approaching air raid overhead- The STEADY SHAKE of the table legs all around pulls out to reveal- BEATRICE ROBERTS [early 50's] austere, crouched next to MARGARET under a wide kitchen table along with ALFRED ROBERTS [early/mid 50's] a cumbersome man and MURIEL ROBERTS [21 yrs]. The sound of an air-raid siren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did someone cover the butter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All look at one another in a panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly MARGARET scrabbles out from under the table, all look on with horror-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret-

dialogues.speaker: INT. SHOP. GRANTHAM. 1943. DUSK.
dialogues.text: MARGARET scooping up the butter cover slamming it quickly over the thin slice of butter left in the butter dish before sliding it into the cold cupboard underneath the counter. SUDDENLY the shop illuminates- A DISTANT EXPLOSION. MARGARET momentarily paralyzed before, running back towards the back parlour to resume her place under the table. INT. BACK PARLOUR. SHOP. GRANTHAM. 1943. DUSK. MARGARET scrabbles underneath. ALFRED surreptitiously pats her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shrugs, flushing with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, no matter what they do, it'll be business as usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DRONE of the air raid dissolving away- INT. SHOP, GRANTHAM. 1945. DAY. A boy and girl look on as MARGARET measures flour on the shop scales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two of the small beef, Mr. Roberts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET glances up at her father serving further down the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the life blood of any community? It's business....

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALL. GRANTHAM. 1943. DAY
dialogues.text: ALFRED on a small town hall stage behind a makeshift podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just big business but small businesses, like mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOFT press of MEN all around, MARGARET, a lone woman amongst them, peering over shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passing/hushed aside) Margaret!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEATRICE tuts, shoving a tray in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUPS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sinks a little, taking the tray, and glances back at ALFRED just visible on a stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We on this island are strong. We're self-reliant. Sometimes we're plain bloody minded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOW AT THE BACK OF THE HALL, holding a tray loaded with dirty cups, MARGARET watches her father, back turned to the kitchen filled with WOMEN and YOUNG GIRLS making tea and washing up cups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we also believe in helping each other. And I don't mean by state hand-outs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sweeps outside the shop, glancing across the street at- THREE PRETTY GIRLS dolled up for the evening and arms linked, crossing on the other side of the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, do you want to come to the pictures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET's eyes catch on the glitter of a broach in passing. They turn to look at her WHISPERING and GIGGLING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't come, she's got to study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FLUSH of MARGARET'S skin -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Hoity Toity!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STING OF EMBARRASSMENT.

dialogues.speaker: THE SENSE OF THE PRETTY GIRLS WHISPERING ABOUT HER, EYES
dialogues.text: TRAVELLING OVER her disparagingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never run with the crowd, Margaret. Go your own way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SWAY of a SKIRT as they walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (close to) Open it then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a telegram addressed to MARGARET ROBERTS, 1-3 North Parade, Grantham. MARGARET'S father ALFRED, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) I've got a place at Oxford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALFRED bear-hugs MARGARET awkwardly. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY. MARGARET at her desk, the ghost of a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let me down Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHINK of a teacup- MARGARET looks down the corridor in expectation at BEATRICE standing at the sink working the SQUEAK of the cloth against a stubborn tea stain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEATRICE comes down the corridor into the shop, wiping her hands on a cloth. ALFRED goes to hand BEATRICE the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head) My hands are still damp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEATRICE turns and walks back to where she came from. MARGARET looks back at the letter, heart bursting, trying to contain her joy. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY. MARGARET looks down, pen in hand, the words Margaret Roberts newly signed in the front cover. She tears the page out. INT. BEDROOM. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT.DAY. MARGARET napping in bed. The still of the bedroom, caught in the half light of a late afternoon- A hand slides a teacup onto the bedside table - The flicker of MARGARET's eyelids-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passing/hushed aside) Margaret!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEATRICE tuts, shoving a tray in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUPS!

dialogues.speaker: PRESENT -
dialogues.text: MARGARET stirs again, blinking awake. DENIS sits by the window. He is bent over a pair of spectacles, wrapping wire around one of the arms with a pair of pliers. Other items of clothing of his are on Margaret's couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without taking his eyes of the job) They're talking about you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The murmur of JUNE on the phone-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun's not quite over the yard arm. Time for tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phone rings, O.S. MARGARET considers DENIS now wearing a pink turban and confronts the extraordinary head-gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got on your head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS smiles, throwing back his head, the swathe of pink fabric from his turban hanging down ridiculously-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Found it in the cupboard and thought bugger it, it's Friday, why not fancy dress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sits drinking her tea, JUNE's hushed tones almost audible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET strains to hear-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bosslady no like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes a shushing motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if to a bad dog) No, Denis, Bosslady no like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET resumes listening. The door ajar, the sounds of life just audible outside-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's taken Carol so long to get her to agree to this. She's been so reluctant to let his things go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS sinks onto the bed, bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking) Feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tuts and adjusts his legs so that his shoes don't dirty the bedspread. MARGARET stands, ear pressed close to the open door-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can never be sure she's taking her medication...I think sometimes she hides them..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, rumbled!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET looks back at her cup of tea, spots two pills resting in the tea cup. She considers the pills, pops them in her mouth, drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's definitely more distracted than usual today.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BEDROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DAY.
dialogues.text: A shout in the street. A woman's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I suggest you remove the sticker from the back of your car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret looks through the net curtains and sees CAROL THATCHER[early 50's] just visible stepping out of a taxi, remonstrating with the driver, clutching her purse and waving her credit card at him with rising irritation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then take the sticker off! I call that false advertising! I would say keep the change, but there isn't any change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scotch being poured. The cap not quite going back on the whisky bottle. A frantic fumble for the remotes for the tv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello June, any news? I've brought every bag I could find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High shot of MARGARET sitting in a chair watching TV. As if she has been there a while. CAROL enters with suit carriers in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Ma. Bloody taxi driver. Wouldn't take my card. I said don't have a sticker saying you take Visa and then insist on cash. Can you believe it? I was rummaging around the bottom of my bag. He didn't get a tip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know that you were dropping by today, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Dumping her stuff all over the place) Yes, you said yesterday...You wanted to make a start on Dad's things. The cupboards ? Then I can help you dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET, nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got Michael and-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaqueline...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming for dinner tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. (turning up the TV) We're having halibut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On TV, images of a bombed street,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God. Isn't it terrible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET nods, both silently listening to the drone of the newscaster-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think it's Al Quaida -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The charred remains of cars, desperate people running, a rescue operation midway- MARGARET blinks, inwardly reeling from the images-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denis!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick Flash: Denis in pyjamas, brushing his teeth in a hotel bathroom, glances at her through the open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be fine. Come on, get your head down, it's ten to three, for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos outside the Grand Hotel in the aftermath of the bomb. The injured are pulled through the rubble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ten to three this morning an explosion extensively damaged the Grand Hotel in Brighton, scene of the Conservative Party conference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Where the Prime Minister and a number of her cabinet were staying. They escaped unhurt -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WHIR of SIRENS- The BLUR of FIRE ENGINE LIGHTS- The image of a BODY being stretchered out of the rubble by FIREFIGHTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five people have died, many others are injured, some critically. The IRA have claimed responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS and MARGARET sit in their coats covering MARGARET's evening dress and DENIS pyjamas. Both looking out in silent shock at the devastated Grand hotel, reflected on the glass of the car windows. MARGARET looks on with quiet, sobering despair, still numb with shock. DENIS looks at her. He grips her hand. They sit, fingers locked. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY. Close on MARGARET's hand and whisky glass. Shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing up) We must release a statement, offering our condolences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure they've already-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must never, ever, ever give in to terrorists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sees JUNE and CAROL exchange looks of `oh dear...' INT.BEDROOM. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT.DUSK. MARGARET sits in a dressing gown at a dressing table, staring at her reflection. CAROL stands behind her, holding up several dresses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now ma, are we going long or just below the knee tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, below the knee I should think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches, irritated, as CAROL reaches to move a pile of DENIS' clothes-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Don't move those. I haven't finished sorting them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL settles beside her on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you went out today...You mustn't go out on your own Mummy. We've talked about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was no milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call Robert he'll get it for you if June's not up-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not for the knackers yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From behind-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now take it easy, Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS just visible, perched on the bed, looks up from doing the crossword in the newspaper-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one is saying that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I can't go out to buy a pint of milk then what is the world coming to. Really Carol, please don't fuss about it. You've always been like this, fuss fuss fuss. You must find something better to do with your time. It's most unattractive in a woman. When I was your age the last thing I wanted to do was fuss around my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence- CAROL, inwardly stung quietly busying herself, forcing all emotion away. MARGARET hesitates catching DENIS' eye, with quiet warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four down, 9 letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS withdraws into his crossword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something b something t something n...something something somthing...Refusal to change course-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obstinate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS writes, pleased. CAROL looks up, with quiet bemusement-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET deflects, pointing to a necklace in CAROL's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearls. I'll wear the pearls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL slips them onto MARGARET'S neck and fastens them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There they are. My little twins. Thank you, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The murmur of conversation- CAROL tails MARGARET, steady on the approach towards the drawing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nearly all familiar faces, William, Michael and his lovely wife-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL smiles, clearly reassured-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then there's Peter, James R and James T and that very nice man-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - we met last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I remember-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's bringing his new lady friend just to mix it up a bit. We're rather short on women - but I'm sure we'll manage-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always preferred the company of men-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL gestures ahead, MARGARET nods, reticent, yet forcing herself on, she hesitates at the door, her hand trembling on the handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up of a shoe being rubbed on a calf. A young hand hesitating on a door handle. INT. SITTING ROOM. HOUSE. DARTFORD. 1949. EVENING. A 1950's drinks party- A bank of stuffy GREY SUITED MEN pontificating and their WIVES lost in a separate polite conversation-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Miss Roberts. Hoping to be chosen as our candidate for parliament.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young MARGARET [24yrs] stylish in a suit, straight from work, stands clutching her handbag, oddly out of place amidst the neat 50's chintz. A bank of sporting prints collage a wall. A bespectacled YOUNG DENIS THATCHER (30's) glances up from his drink, taking her in. INT.DINING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT.EVENING. The MURMUR of dinner party conversation-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't like coalitions, never have...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET's POV of her fingers absently grazing a confusing array of cutlery laid out in place setting in front of her. Her confused face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start on the outside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and work your way in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long table packed with silverware. She looks back at her ornate and rather hideous starter, a tiny wobbling savoury confection in aspic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Attlee has his sights set on the steel industry, you mark my words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll be nationalizing the bloody air next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, hold your breath, sir, that's government property!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So was your father a political man, too, Miss Roberts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, to his core. And Mayor of Grantham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a grocer as well!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ears prick up around the table. The Host is lost for something to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did you help, err, in the...shop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. It was a family business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very good starting point for the political life, I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That and a degree from Oxford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The put-down, though not intentional, causes Denis to smile. MARGARET catches the smile. She remains unruffled and goes back to her food, picking up a knife and fork, working her way in, teasing her hors d'oeuvres. INT. DINING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE.LONDON.PRESENT.EVENING. MARGARET sits oddly removed, hand instinctively covering her wine glass, as a WINE WAITER hovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hushed aside to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whisky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MURMUR of conversation all around- INT. DINING ROOM. HOUSE. DARTFORD. 1949. EVENING. Pudding is on the go and Margaret is warming to her theme.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I do think is that a man should be encouraged to stand on his own two feet. Yes we help people of course we help people. But for those that can do, they must just get up and do. And if something's wrong, they shouldn't just whine about it, they should get in there and DO something about it, change things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The female guests exchange glances. A half-chuckle from someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect, Miss Roberts, what may have served in Grantham-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can serve very well for the people of Dartford too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A general sense of quiet incredulity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know much more than those who have never lived on a limited income. Just like the man or woman on the street, when I am short one week, I have to make economies the next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing like a slice of fiscal responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man might call it fiscal responsibility, a woman might call it good housekeeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure a home economics lesson is quite what the Dartford constituents need. They see industry being nationalized, the unions on the up, the pound on the slide...whoever can sort that lot out - he's my man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denis lets out a spontaneous guffaw as the host and hostess exchange looks. He signals `Get them out of here'. The men rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies shall we ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Roberts, do join the ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladies scurry to the sitting room. Margaret is the last to leave. INT. SITTING ROOM. DARTFORD. 1949. EVENING. As Margaret closes the door to the dining room -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. That's told us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men laugh raucously. She turns to the ladies who are regrouping at the fireplace and regarding her with suspicion. INT.DINING ROOM.   CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. EVENING. The aftermath of the muted dinner party- MARGARET at the helm, a small whisky just visible nestled next to her wine glass. She is flushed and nicely mellow surrounded by mainly MALE GUESTS-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Margaret, how would you have dealt with this if you'd been Prime Minister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET looks at him, her flicker of bemusement. ...slowly registering across the faces of her FRIENDS and COLLEAGUES including CAROL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bombings, mummy. Today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET still lost

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just talking about them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET deflects, reaching for her glass, it trembles unsteady in her grasp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, uhm, yes - we have always lived alongside evil. But it has never been so patient, so avid for carnage, so eager to carry innocents with it into oblivion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, would you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Western civilization must root out this evil, wherever it hides, or she risks defeat at the hands of global terror in a nuclear age. Unimaginable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appreciative murmur of agreements amongst the listening party-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prime Minister gave a very good statement I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Clever man. Quite a smoothie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter- INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. NIGHT. MARGARET says final farewells to a guest. He walks away as another couple approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mind if I sit down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting down on a nearby chair, MARGARET looks with feigned recollection at the FEMALE GUEST as she sinks down on the ground in front of her, gripping MARGARET's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you speak at conference in 1984 in Brighton just after the IRA bombed the Grand Hotel. You were remarkable. I hope you appreciate what an inspiration you have been for women like myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET hesitates, smiles, nods to herself, considering-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It used to be about trying to do something. Now its about trying to be someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FEMALE GUEST nods and scrambled to her feet, clearly concerned, shooting a look to her HUSBAND standing beside her, waiting to depart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well anyway, I...thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sits alone. In the background, the chatter of Carol saying final farewells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great to see you, thank you very much for coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. It was lovely, absolutely lovely. And I'm so pleased to see your mother looking so well.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRESSING ROOM. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT.NIGHT.
dialogues.text: A mirror lined dressing room- CAROL helps MARGARET with her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK...hold on to me...that's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET struggles with the catch on her pearls

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you do the clasp, I can't quite -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL hurries to help her, MARGARET quietly concedes. Fingers fumble to unclasp the pearls-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL drops the pearls into a jewelry box, close to MARGARET, staring back at their reflections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got an eyelash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL catches the stray eyelash on the tip of her finger, holding it close to MARGARET, with a smile-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make a wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET, closes her eyes until- MARGARET blows. She opens them smiles. CAROL smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke to Doctor Michael today-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET glances away, deflecting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is very good and very expensive-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET ignores her-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I know you're not due to see him for another month but I've spoken to him and he can fit you in tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for a check up. (silence) Ma please-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does Mark think about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Tell him to come up. I want to talk to him about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL, hesitates, with concern-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark's with Sarah and the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET nods, heading through into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well tell him to come up and see me after he's kissed them good night, would you Carol darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET, sitting on her bed, glances expectantly towards the door. Carol sits down beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not here Mummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET hesitates, CAROL using all her might, not to crumble under MARGARET's cool gaze-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark lives in South Africa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET inwardly flinches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you are not Prime Minister anymore and Dad is...Dad is dead-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look exhausted, dear. You really must try to get some sleep. Taxis'll be few and far between at this hour...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Righty-ho. Night night Ma. Sleep well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slam of a door. MARGARET sits, alone. INT. SADLERS WELLS.   LONDON. 1950. NIGHT. MARGARET'S POV of Denis turning to her in the theatre. He smiles. MARGARET's FINGERS absently grazing over the programme, in time with the music- SUDDENLY a closed fist reaches out, then opens to reveal a sugar mouse. Margaret's fingers reach for it, but it's teasingly withdrawn. Finally, she takes its. She turns to smile at DENIS, her face is glowing with happiness- INT. TOWN HALL 1950. NIGHT. MARGARET sits on the edge of a trestle table, scrunching a rosette in her hand. The Town Hall is empty save for a couple of Volunteers stacking chairs and sweeping the floor. The litter of election night is everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-four-year-old Miss Margaret Roberts lost her bid to win a seat in Parliament today, but she has put new life into the Dartford Conservative Association. Winning candidate Mr Dodds had better watch out, this bright young woman is on his tail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS appears in the doorway, carrying fish and chips. He slides them down in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET almost smiles. Then sinks once more into misery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on...Hang on...Hang on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS fishes in his pocket pulling out a hip flask. An impromptu supper made. MARGARET takes in the aftermath of rosettes, the whiff of defeat all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shaved thousands off their majority. You did splendidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not splendidly enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah I see. Self pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET eyes him, mid chip-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one is saying you don't need a safe seat. You deserve a safe seat. But it does not come unless you learn to play the game a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is fuming but he regroups with a big breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a grocer's daughter-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fiercely) -And proud of being-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs her hand, silencing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - in their eyes. A single grocer's daughter. But if you were to become the wife of a moderately successful businessman-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, we see MARGARET taken by surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd get to parliament, and I'd get to be the happiest man in- in wherever they select you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, will you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is genuinely stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is frozen. Then she begins to smile and nod her head and smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans over and kisses her, long and passionately until

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you so much but...I will never be one of those women Denis - who stays silent and pretty on the arm of her husband. Or remote and alone in the kitchen doing the washing up for that matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to retain the moment) We'll get a help for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans forward to kiss her again but she pulls away a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - one's life must matter, Denis. Beyond the cooking and the cleaning and the children, one's life must mean more than that - I cannot die washing up a tea cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits up and stares as if seeing her for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it Denis, say you understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I want to marry you, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him. A CHINK of a TEACUP- They pull apart. FLUSHED and GIGGLING on seeing- A LONE WOMAN enters the hall, cleaning up the last of the tea cups, and generally tidying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET smiles her joy at him as `SHALL WE DANCE' swells. And now she's in his arms as they dance, swirling through the election debris, eyes only for each other. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. NIGHT. MARGARET now on all fours, struggling with her glasses. A pile of DVD's on the floor, The KING and I amongst them momentarily catching her eye until- A DVD with hand-written scrawl that we can't quite read. MARGARET flicks open the box, struggling to get the DVD out. Fiddling with the DVD player, MARGARET puts in the disc and considers, squinting at the remote, trying to make the DVD player work until, suddenly... Super 8 footage - 1959 Children on a beach in wind-swept, grainy super 8. Denis with a golf club and ping pong balls practicing his drive from a tee, sending ball after ball skying into the sea. Mark and Carol charge into the water to retrieve them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There they are, my little twins. Mark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS approaches the camera laughing and appears to take hold of it. MARGARET is seen sitting on a wobbly camping stool, hardly dressed for the beach, surrounded by papers weighed held down by pebbles. She merrily returns to her work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornwall, wasn't it? Bloody hell... Look at `em, little imps. You never really got golf, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS sits behind her on the sofa in a dressing gown, watching the footage. She sips her whisky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do, don't I? You're drinking too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS looks at MARGARET, unwavering. She resumes a search

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not like you. Looking back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET SUDDENLY presses rewind on the remote, clutched in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't want to dig around too deep, M. Don't know what you might find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rapid rewind of Denis swinging his golf club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can rewind it, but you can't change it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She freezes the image of him turning to camera, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They grow up so fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret turns with something to say, but Denis doesn't seem to be there anymore. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT.NIGHT. Now on the screen, Mark on a swing. MARGARET'S face softens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and rushes towards the camera, whooshing past it. Without breaking step, suddenly, he's in the room, running past Margaret, still cheering and whooping. MARGARET's hand, just skimming MARK's golden curls. As he moves on, MARGARET's curiosity caught following him out and down the corridor of Chester Square, seeing the Mark and Carol disappear round a corner. INT. HALLWAY. HOUSE. FARNBOROUGH. KENT. 1959. DAWN. The view beyond-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Eric Deakins, Labour... 13,437...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CRUNCH of gravel as CAROL and MARK race across the drive towards a blue ford car, covered with Tory blue streamers and a VOTE FOR THATCHER poster scrawled with the words Victory. MARGARET flicks open the box, struggling to get the DVD out. Mark and Carol charge into the water to retrieve them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There they are, my little twins. Mark...

dialogues.text: DENIS approaches the camera laughing and appears to take hold of it. MARGARET is seen sitting on a wobbly camping stool, hardly dressed for the beach, surrounded by papers weighed held down by pebbles. She merrily returns to her work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornwall, wasn't it? Bloody hell... Look at `em, little imps. You never really got golf, did you?

dialogues.text: DENIS sits behind her on the sofa in a dressing gown, watching the footage. She sips her whisky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do, don't I? You're drinking too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS looks at MARGARET, unwavering. She resumes a search MARGARET fingers brush dark panelled walls, making her way along endless corridors. Gothic arches, venerable busts, wood panelling and stone. MARGARET's pov as she stays to the side of the impressive corridor. She passes men in suits and groups. Others come towards her and notice her. Her POV as she pushes open a first door `TEA ROOM' - a circle of men turn round in chorus as if something with three heads has appeared. POV of a second opening door marked MEMBERS. A row of urinals. Two headless bodies come towards the camera, scrambling to zip up their flies. POV of the promise of sanctuary. LADY MEMBERS. The door opens onto a cupboard sized space. An ironing board. A sea of men's Oxford shoes from ground level. A pair of woman's shoes appear amongst them. They go on tip toe. From above we see Margaret's hat amongst the sea of mens heads and shoulders. Margaret is carried along in the sea of MALE MP's OXFORD SHOES. AIREY NEAVE [Extremely dapper, friendly 43] approaches MARGARET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Thatcher ! Airey Neave. Welcome to the madhouse. Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors swing open-

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS CHAMBER. 1974. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET, now SECRETARY OF STATE FOR EDUCATION, on the front bench, wearing a neat blue suit and a hat, a phalanx of MINISTERS sitting beside and around her, BLUE and GREY SUITED MEN, almost at first glance indistinguishable, with PRIME MINISTER EDWARD HEATH (late 50's), neat, effete, slumped rather forlornly on the bench. MARGARET, her speech and papers in her hand is fighting hard but the OPPOSITION LABOUR BENCHES scent blood - and they literally bray, getting to their feet and shaking their order papers in her face. The SPEAKER tries to control the chamber but his VOICE is almost lost in the bedlam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Right Honourable Lady the Secretary of State for Education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The right honourable gentleman knows that we have no choice but to shut down the schools!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cries of `Shame!' From the opposition. The chamber reduced to a bear-pit. HEATH glum and offering no help to MARGARET whose voice becomes increasingly shrill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because his union paymasters have called a strike deliberately to cripple our economy. Teachers cannot teach when there is no heating, no lighting in their classrooms. And I ask the honourable gentleman, whose fault is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Methinks the Right Honourable lady doth screech to much. If she wants us to take her seriously she must learn to calm down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OPPOSITION BENCHES love that, rocking in their seats, laughing... falsely of course. But MARGARET is aware that there are many MEN behind her, on the government benches, who are also sniggering in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the right honorable gentleman could perhaps attend more closely to WHAT I am saying, rather than HOW I am saying it, he may receive a valuable education in spite of himself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her opposite number Shadow Minister looks almost smug: smiling, pointing a finger at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why has this Conservative government failed? Why has it forced so many in the public sector into taking strike action to save their own jobs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It brings the OPPOSITION benches to their feet, shouting, applauding, stamping...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WESTMINSTER STREET. 1974. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET walking with AIREY NEAVE towards Downing Street for a Cabinet Meeting. All around, heaped high on either side as far as the eye can see are bags of rubbish. But not neatly stacked, just thrown there, many of them rotting down, spilling their filthy, putrid contents onto the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minister, the breakdown of essential public services - transport, electricity, sanitation is not the fault of the trades unions but of this Conservative government in which you so shamefully serve!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stench is awful - and MARGARET'S expression reflects that as she picks her way through. INT. CABINET ROOM. DOWNING STREET. 1974. NIGHT. The ranks of BESPECTACLED GREY-SUITED MINISTERS   at the Cabinet table, including GEOFFREY HOWE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So these power cuts will continue unless we can reach a compromise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD HEATH is in mid-flow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The miners are asking for a 35% increase in wages. Obviously we can't go anywhere near that. The unions are not our enemies and never have been. We want - and have always wanted - the broadest consensus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MINISTERS nod. MARGARET determinedly edges a little forward so that she is in equal line with the other MALE MINISTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure we are all in agreement that we must do nothing for the moment that will further inflame the current situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear hear, Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET leans forward for a better view, trying to catch his eye. HEATH wavers, mid-speech. All turn to look at MARGARET - who sits unwavering. HEATH resumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - the fact of the matter is, it's absolutely crucial that we are seen by the public to be acting as conciliators and not aggressors. (Finally acknowledging Margaret) Yes, Education Secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes TURN on her again, hearing the reservation in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prime Minister, with the Miners' leader calling today for the army to mutiny in support of the strikes, this seems the wrong time for conciliation.

dialogues.speaker: SUDDENLY ALL THE LIGHTS GO OUT.
dialogues.text: A lot of `bloody hell' `oh for god's sake'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be patient. They'll come back on in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beam of light cuts through, just for an instant picking out HEATH'S moon-like face surrounded by darkness. MARGARET holds the small torch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A snigger, then the lights flicker back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your thoughts are duly noted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET turns of the torch and clicks her handbag shut in satisfaction. Heath's words echo in her head, `compromise...compromise...compromise...' An inward look as she's caught by a memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We on this island are strong. We're self-reliant. Napoleon called us a nation of shopkeepers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The packed town hall, ALFRED ROBERTS in full flow on stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He meant it as an insult but to me it's a compliment. That's why he couldn't beat us, and that's why Hitler can't beat us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd of men applaud. The lone woman in their midst, YOUNG MARGARET watches her father, face aglow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We Conservatives believe in giving people the freedom and opportunity to fulfil their own potential, especially the young. There's no good in pretending we're all equal, we're not all the same, never have been, never will be. We should encourage our children to aspire to achieve more than we have, for our children today will be the leaders of tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. STREET. CENTRAL LONDON. 1974. DAWN
dialogues.text: ...CAROL and MARGARET seated, driving steadily along a deserted street. MARGARET thoughtful as the radio plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 1974 and you'd think it was WWII. Blackouts, no petrol. It's a mess. Heath should resign now and make way for someone who's not afraid to tackle the unions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL'S nervous prattle begins to break through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear, it's all gone completely out of my head. My driving instructor thinks I should pass but I feel as if I've hardly had any lessons. Ridiculous isn't it? Maybe third time lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. The only thing you should remember is that everyone else is either reckless or inept. And often both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET eyes the road, gesturing CAROL to move forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One must be brave if one is to take the wheel-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right-o.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move over... Move to your right a little bit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if I move to the right aren't I on the wrong side of the road?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he's in the way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the right. Move to the right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A yelp from CAROL as the car swerves a little, narrowly missing a lone CYCLIST-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So sorry! Terribly sorry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET throws a wave from the wound down window. The CYCLIST swerves on recognizing her, watching as the car goes round and round the square, almost balletic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look at me, driving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL's squeals of delight, let loose on the open road. The tyres screech on the corner. INT. KITCHEN. FLOOD STREET. LONDON. 1974. DAWN. Laughter - VOICES on the approach-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks Ma, that was terrific! I really feel I've got a handle on it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL and MARGARET entering kitchen, still giddy from their adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have seen us, Pa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS in his dressing gown burning toast and attempting to make breakfast -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been trying to make breakfast? For Goodness sake, Denis!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS scrapes down the toast, eggs boiling in the pan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can boil a bloody egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummy took me for a test drive - We went absolutely everywhere. All over the place -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sudden/cutting in) I've decided. I'm going to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET smiles, a growing resolution gripping her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to run for Leader of the Party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL'S utter disappointment on seeing she has lost MARGARET already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silly me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL storms out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after) Good luck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the time I thought I was having a driving lesson, it was all about my mother, just for a change!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she on about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's her driving test this morning!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying you want to be Prime Minister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with false patience) What I'm saying is that someone must force the point, say the unsayable. None of these men have the guts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sees the burnt toast and energetically starts clearing up and putting more bread under the grill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prime Minister has been very loyal to you, MT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries, with a trembling hand, to scoop boiled eggs from the pan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's weak, and he's weakened the party. One must know when to go. (glancing at him) You're shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS pulls his arm away, sending boiled eggs flying. SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodness me! What is the matter with everyone this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. He looks utterly fragile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've told you what the matter is. The business is a bit rocky at the moment and the Doctor thinks I need a rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do you need a rest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's almost challenging. He doesn't answer and she doesn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We both know that it's highly unlikely that I would ever be elected leader, I'll never be elected leader. But I will run. I will run. Just to nip at their heels and make them reaffirm the principles on which the Conservative Party must stand. There's so much to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) You're insufferable, Margaret, do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denis, you married someone who is committed to public service, you knew that. And it is my duty -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Don't call it duty. It's ambition which has got you this far. Ambition. And the rest of us, me, the children, we can all go to hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SLAM of the door, DENIS gone-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about me, I'll be fine!

dialogues.speaker: INT. SITTING ROOM. CHESTER SQ. PRESENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MARGARET and DENIS sit on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: South Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. FLOOD STREET. LONDON. 1974. DAWN
dialogues.text: MARGARET eats breakfast alone, engrossed in the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many days passed before you realized I was gone? Probably had to ask the cleaning woman where I was.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SITTING ROOM. CHESTER SQ. PRESENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MARGARET grips her whiskey, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did I lose track of everyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too busy climbing the greasy pole MT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cutting in -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Thatcher I understand you recently visited the United States of America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET'S attention is caught by an old interview, playing on the TV. She leans forward. On screen, she sits in a neat hat, leaning forward eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it you took away from that visit which may be of value here in Great Britain?

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO. LONDON. 1975. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MARGARET perched on a chair, smiling at the TV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh that's rather easy to answer, actually. They are unafraid of success.

dialogues.speaker: INT. REECE'S OFFICE. LONDON. 1975. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET is watching the same interview on a TV monitor. She is watching herself intently, as are REECE and AIREY NEAVE. They are polar opposites, REECE flamboyant to NEAVE's bluff. She sounds very plummy, like a Conservative party wife from the shires. And she wears a hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We in Great Britain and in Europe are formed mainly by our history. They on the other hand are formed by their philosophy. Not by what has been, but by what can be. Oh, we have a great deal that we can learn from them, yes. Oh yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET is trapped in the moment - but the two men exchange a glance. NEAVE freezes the picture. MARGARET smiles uneasily, like someone expecting a compliment. REECE considers her, long and hard. It is a little unsettling until-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well er...For a start, that hat has got to go. And the pearls. In fact I think all hats may have to go. You look and sound like a privileged Conservative wife and we've already got her vote. You've got lovely hair but we need to do something with it - to make it more-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Give it more impact. But the main thing is your voice. Its too high. It has no authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Methinks the Lady doth screech too much

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People don't want to be harangued by a woman or hectored. Persuaded yes. That `oh yes' at the end of the interview, that's authoritative, that's the voice of a leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all very well to talk about changing my voice, Mr Reece, but for some of my colleagues to imagine me as their leader would be like imagining, I don't know, being led into battle by their chambermaid. It's my background, and my sex. No matter how I've tried, and I have tried, to fit in, I will never be truly one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both REECE and NEAVE are aware that she has spoken very nakedly - and is thus extremely vulnerable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I may say so - I think that's your trump card. You're flying in the face of everything the Tories have been thus far. It's really very exciting. One simply has to maximise your appeal, bring out all your qualities and make you look, and sound, like the leader that you could be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got it in you to go the whole distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prime Minister?! Oh no. Oh no no no. In Britain? There will be no female Prime Minister here, not in my lifetime. No. And I told Airey, I don't expect to win the leadership, but I am going to run. Just to shake up the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEAVE moves in intently-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Respectfully, Margaret, I disagree. If you want to change this party, lead it. If you want to change the country, lead it. What we're talking about here today is surface. What's crucial is that you hold your course, and stay true to who you are. Never be anything other than yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET, though flattered, looks sceptical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave us to do the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I am in your hands. I may be persuaded to surrender the hat. But the pearls were a gift from my husband on the birth of our twins and they are absolutely non-negotiable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET smiles at them.

dialogues.speaker: INT. REHEARSAL ROOM. NATIONAL THEATRE. LONDON. 1975. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET stands humming, a THEATRICAL COACH presses her hand to MARGARET'S stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And...bring it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET hums lower, tries to project her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maaaaaaaaaaaa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, I think we can loose the handbag, Mrs Thatcher...Hands down the sides...Because this isn't really about the voice, it's about belief...A nice deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REECE and NEAVE are watching and monitoring the performance. DENIS, though present, is having a crafty fag by the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're calling Mr Thatcher, how would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET looks over at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls) Denis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I want more authority, I want conviction, I want -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little more authority) Denis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, one more time, deep breath -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts on her new, lower voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And DENIS reacts immediately, like a guilty thing surprised, stabbing out his cigarette, turning quickly towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes MT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET makes her way through a crowd of applauding workers in crisp white uniforms. Like them, she wears a white cap on her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are the backbone of our nation! Small firms like Loveday's Ice Cream. How are you? So nice to meet you ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General merriment as MARGARET, now inside an ice-cream van, has a go at dispensing an ice cream from the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just have a small one, because I'm watching my figure. (handing the cone out) That's for you young man!

dialogues.speaker: INT. HAIR SALON. LONDON. 1975. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET is having new hair colour and the colourist is 75 percent through putting her hair in foil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I passionately believe it's the growth of small businesses into larger ones that is critical for Britain's future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REECE and NEAVE are sitting nearby, both of them reading the Financial Times. EXT. YARD. ICE CREAM FACTORY. DAY. MARGARET among the ladies again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has to be something icy on a stick for Denis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (returning to her subject) That's the only way we will produce jobs, real jobs, jobs that sustain.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HAIR SALON. LONDON. 1975. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET sitting under the dryer, cooking her new hair, still correcting paperwork while REECE and NEAVE look on, twiddling their thumbs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FACTORY. LONDON. 1975. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET is standing on an impromptu stage outside a factory. She has a hard hat on her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Trade Union Movement was founded to protect workers. Now it persecutes them. It stops them from working. It is killing jobs and it is bringing this country to its knees. I say enough. It's time to get up. It's time to go to work. It's time to put the Great back into Great Britain!

dialogues.speaker: INT. HAIR SALON. 1975. DAY
dialogues.text: The bouffant is now apparent. REECE AND NEAVE watch in awe.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BACKSTAGE. CONFERENCE HALL. BRIGHTON. 1979. DAY
dialogues.text: A darkened backstage. MARGARET, clutching her speech, goes over her lines. A FEMALE AIDE sprays her hair. She looks up, starts to move towards the light. AIREY NEAVE is suddenly next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give `em hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks her up and down, with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look magnificent. Next stop Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Airey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As from the stage -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The leader of the Conservative Party, Margaret Thatcher!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET pushes back her shoulders and walks into battle to the sound of GROWING APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MAIN HALL. CONFERENCE HALL. BRIGHTON. 1979. DAY
dialogues.text: BRITAIN NEEDS THE CONSERVATIVES bannered overhead and hung with Union Jacks. MARGARET a swathe of blue, as she passes through her GREY SUITED CABINET. From behind she stands, arms outstretched, accepting the applause, a shock of bright blonde hair as she stands before a sea of CONSERVATIVE DELEGATES holding up letter cards WE LOVE YOU MAGGIE! Wedges of fanatical party faithful on their feet in a kind of rapture. The blessed Margaret ! DENIS just visible with REECE, HOWE, PYM, HESELTINE and several other GREY SUITED MINISTERS of her cabinet, seated close behind now jumping to their feet, with obvious relief and delight -

dialogues.speaker: RAPTUROUS APPLAUSE, FLASH BULBS POPPING
dialogues.text: MARGARET smiles, glorious, catching DENIS' eye. He is brimming with pride. AIREY NEAVE beams at his protegee. INT. CORRIDOR. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DAY. Close on a photograph of MARGARET and AIREY NEAVE. MARGARET sits looking at it, her coat on, her handbag on her lap. INT. UNDERGROUND CAR PARK. HOUSE OF COMMONS. 1979. EVE. MARGARET is loading papers and files into the boot of her car. AIREY NEAVE drives towards her, winding down his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night Margaret. My money's on the filly to win!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks Airey. Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs and drives towards the exit of the car park. As MARGARET closes the boot and opens the door to get in the car suddenly there's a MASSIVE EXPLOSION, the sound magnified by being in the cavernous underground. For a few seconds we don't know what's happened. Through the smoke we see MARGARET running up the ramp towards us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, no! Airey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her POV of the fireball of Neave's car. As Margaret looks in horror at the scene. Her shattered face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Irish National Liberation Army has claimed responsibility for the death of Airey Neave, Margaret Thatcher's spokesman on Northern Ireland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET on the conference podium, blinking back tears. Behind her, Denis' face etched with the same sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STEPS. HOUSE OF COMMONS. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET walks alone down the grand stairway, sombre, deep in thought. INT. CORRIDOR. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DAY. MARGARET looks up from the photograph, tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to change the party, lead it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to change the country, lead it. You've got it in you to go the whole distance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On MARGARET as memories flood in. A TV headline announces: ELECTION 1979.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONFERENCE HALL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MARGARET on the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, as the test draws near, I ask your help. That together we can shake off the shackles of socialism and restore to greatness this country that we love so much. And the only way is for the Conservative Party to win!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black streak of MARGARET'S car, a blur of colour, faces, waving flags - TV footage of polling night. Swingometers, pollsters, impressionistic snatches of reported speech. More footage of PEOPLE coming out of polling stations. Jubilant crowds applauding.. MARGARET, silhouetted in her iconic stance, arms aloft... INT. CAR. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1979. DAY. MARGARET peering out of the window, hands sunk in the lap, a flash of the Royal blue fabric of her skirt, clenched in fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Friday the 4th of May, an historic day for Britain, a Conservative government led by Mrs. Thatcher is set to lead -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Ghandi in India, but never in the West has there been a woman Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place that she has secured in British history, as the first woman ever to be invited to form a government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bonus of one of the most famous addresses in the world, Number 10 Downing Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOISE. FLAGS. BANNERS read `We LOVE YOU MAGGIE' blur through the window, an abstract cacophony of noise and colour-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it, steady the buffs old girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clasps her hand for a moment as MARGARET smiles at him. The door swings open- EXT. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1979. DAY. The CAMERA from behind on MARGARET rising up out of the car, to face a waiting PRESS CORP. The jostle of a POLICE OFFICER, DENIS and OTHERS press her either side-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should just like to say that I take very seriously the trust the British people placed in me today, and I will work hard every day to live up to that responsibility. And now, I should like to share with you a prayer of St Francis of Assisi: Where there is discord may we bring harmony... Where there is error may we bring truth... Where there is doubt may we bring faith... Where there is despair may we bring hope..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA rises up, high above MARGARET until she is just a blue dot, on the dark tarmac, a lone woman standing facing the circle of cameras and microphones. The door of Number 10 looms ahead. INT. DRAWING ROOM. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1979. DAY. The cheers go over .. The CABINET gathering for a group shot-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoulders back, tummies in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter. Michael Heseltine, standing behind MARGARET, reaches out to smooth a stray lock of her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank you, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
