dialogues.text: MARGARET seated at the heart of her entire CABINET, as if she is royalty. The FLASH of the CAMERA - the image frozen. INT. CORRIDOR. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DAY. The same image, framed on a side table beside MARGARET. The distant hum of a hoover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm perfectly healthy. There's no need for any of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denis appears, his hand inside his shoe, polishing it vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let them look under the bonnet, MT. Check everything is hunky dory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET hesitates. She sits in silence until-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really it's becoming quite tiresome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. (beat) I was on my own for twenty four years before I met you and I can manage perfectly well without you now. So will you please go away and stop bothering me.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONSULTING ROOM. HARLEY STREET. LONDON. PRESENT.DAY
dialogues.text: A distinguished consulting room- MARGARET sits silent, as an EMINENT DOCTOR checks her blood pressure. The beep of the machine, steady and monotonous until-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just look straight at me, straight ahead, that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR scribbles some notes, considering-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you noticing night sweats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hallucinations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET hesitates. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I sleep. Four, five hours a night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you wake early?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I stay up late. I always have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him as if he really should know this about her. The DOCTOR notes this down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just want to keep abreast of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grief is a very natural state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband has been gone for years. Cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol says you've decided to let his things go. Probably a good thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It was my idea. To Oxfam. Perfectly good stuff. People can use these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still it must be a bit disorientating. You are bound to be feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What am I `bound to be feeling'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR looks up from his note taking, hearing the quiet challenge in MARGARET's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People don't `think' any more. They `feel'. `How are you feeling?' `Oh I don't feel comfortable with that' `Oh, I'm so sorry but we, the group were feeling...' D'you know, one of the great problems of our age is that we are governed by people who care more about feelings than thoughts and ideas. (beat) Now thoughts and ideas. That interests me. (beat) Ask me what I am thinking-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR hesitates, letting MARGARET settle until-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you thinking, Margaret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET looks at the DOCTOR, quietly struggling with a fury, threatening to unleash-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your thoughts, for they become words. Watch your words, for they become actions. Watch your actions, for they become habits. Watch your habits, for they become your character. And watch your character, for it becomes your destiny. What we think, we become. My father always said that. (beat) And I think I am fine. (beat) But I do so appreciate your kind concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sudden and persistent buzz of an intercom-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, do please answer that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET holds his gaze, with quiet unwavering steel unsettling the DOCTOR a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might be someone who needs you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR reluctantly answers his intercom- INT. CORRIDOR CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DUSK. JUNE heads up the stairs, MARGARET following behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give Carol a quick ring, let her know we're back, then I'll put your electric blanket on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET nods. Looking through the bannisters, her eyes fall on- A golf ball running along the floor. MARGARET considers, looks up-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady, steady, steady! Damn. Fore!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ball bounces down the wooden stairs. INT. KITCHEN. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DUSK. MARGARET opens the fridge. A cold plated lunch resting on a shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about that medicine man, eh? Ah. Cold supper. Standards are slipping Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET ignores DENIS taking out the plate unwrapping the cellophane off it and placing it on a table, already laid ready for her to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you really gave it to that quack didn't you, darling ? Just like the old days! Hallucinations my eye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS picks up a piece of cucumber from her plate. She absently smacks at his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then you give us all the run around, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET looks at him, silently infuriated. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DUSK. MARGARET pours herself a whiskey. DENIS looms close, serves a splash of soda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you can hear me, sweetheart, so there's no use pretending you can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET turns, ignoring him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough. Denis, enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (saluting) Dismissed!

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DUSK.
dialogues.text: MARGARET sits reading DENIS' spy novel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does it in the end. Kills him-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET slams the book closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why you're being so scratchy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET's eyes dart to the clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not as if you've got anyone else to talk to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaking her head, MARGARET tries to block him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the Himalayan peasant meets the he-bear in his pride -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, it's a marvel to me that you can still quote huge chunks of Kipling but try remembering the name of that woman who's just made you that godawful cold collation... No? Come on... you can do it... month of the year... one syllable... rhymes with moon ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sudden/like a lightbulb) June.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET turns to DENIS, a quiet appalling victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: June! Bingo. Knew you'd get there in the end. "When the Himalayan peasant meets the he-bear in his pride, He shouts to scare the monster, who will often turn aside, but the she-bear thus accosted rends the peasant tooth and nail. For the female of the species is more deadly than the male..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he continues, MARGARET reaches for the remote, turns the television on. She moves onto the radio. Then the stereo. She moves on, talking to herself- A gradual growing cacophony of sound- INT. KITCHEN. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DUSK. MARGARET flicks on mixers, radios, toasters- INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DUSK. The noise almost unbearable now- MARGARET turns on a hi-fi, the TV now on-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I can't hear you then I can't see you. And if I can't see you then you are not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you are not here, I am not going mad. I will not...I will not go mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens them and suddenly freezes on seeing an image of herself, bewildered and leaving Harley Street, caught on the TV-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baroness Thatcher made an apparently routine visit to her doctor today. Although rarely seen in public, Lady Thatcher, the longest serving Prime Minister of the twentieth century, remains a controversial figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET turns up the volume to full, trying to hear over the cacophony of noise the changing images on the TV illuminating her pale face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET barely sees her, eyes riveted to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost lovingly dubbed by the Soviets The Iron Lady, she's also credited, with her friend Ronald Reagan, with a decisive role in the ending of the Cold War. Her supporters claim she transformed the British economy and reversed the country's post-war decline. Her detractors blame her savage public spending cuts and sweeping privatization of -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNE moves like a dervish through the house, muting the television and turning off the last of the appliances- A gradual silence descends until- MARGARET takes in the image of herself on the mute screen, standing bewildered on the steps of Harley Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost to self) I don't recognize myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shelf of a bathroom cabinet. Shaving brush. Razor. Medicaments. MARGARET begins to pull them all off the shelves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I out of the doghouse yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then a pair of glasses. More gently, MARGARET'S hand reaches into the cupboard and takes the glasses in her hand. INT. BEDROOM. HOUSE.CHESTER SQUARE.PRESENT.NIGHT. MARGARET lies in bed, book in her lap, DENIS beside her reading the paper. She closes the book and pulls off her reading glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're unveiling that portrait of me at Number 10 next month. The invitation's on the mantelpiece. So there'll be Churchill, Lloyd George and me. Just the three of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I didn't want any big fuss but they insisted..

dialogues.speaker: SILENCE-
dialogues.text: Lovely little article in The Telegraph... The Woman Who Changed the Face of History..

dialogues.speaker: SILENCE-
dialogues.text: Voices from the past intrude -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Less than two years ago, the Prime Minister quoted St. Francis and talked about bringing faith, hope and harmony to this country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET suddenly reaches out a hand, her hand shaking-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns in bed. Sudden panic, DENIS is gone-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HECKLING chamber as MARGARET sits, facing LABOUR OUTRAGE, the labour leader, FOOT, grips his paper, mid speech-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can the Right Honourable Lady deny, that having brought about the highest level of unemployment since 1934-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET bides her time on the front bench, waiting her turn, surrounded by her CABINET MINISTERS including HOWE, PYM and HESELTINE-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The biggest fall in total output in steel and coal production in one year since 1931. And the biggest collapse in industrial production since 1921.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET remains seemingly calm and serene, and yet one hand quietly grips the bench, her wedding ring tapping against the wood nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can she also accept that her free market economics designed to create a growing middle class ensures that the rich get richer and the poor are irrelevant!

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. STREETS. LONDON. 1980. DAY
dialogues.text: A rising roar of voices -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie Maggie Maggie! Out Out Out! Maggie Maggie Maggie! Out Out Out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET in her car driving through the blur of furious PROTESTORS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're supposed to be a mother! You're not a mother, you're s monster! You're a monster!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP on a button - The STEADY IN and OUT of a needle pulling taut on a thread. MARGARET stands, swathed in a glittering long dinner dress, a SEAMSTRESS stitching a stray button on the front of the bodice on her dress. Geoffrey Howe stands nearby in a dinner jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May we have a word, Prime Minister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bank of MINISTERS, including HESELTINE, PYM, PRIOR, HOWE and GILMOUR, gather before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but in order to arrive at the palace on time, Geoffrey and I are will be walking out of that door in 15 minutes. As you can see -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're running late Margaret, but we have to address this situation in light of tomorrow's blistering press coverage. Blistering! The knives are out. Your draft budget's been leaked, Geoffrey, they are baying for our blood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael we can't possibly buckle at the first sign of difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SCRATCH of PRIOR's hand on unkempt hair-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one is saying we have to buckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But is this really the time to make these spending cuts in the middle of one of the deepest recessions this country has ever experienced?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need a plan of action, Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. A strategy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must be armed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agreed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET stiffens, the needle momentarily hovering mid stitch as MARGARET shifts a little- The SEAMSTRESS resumes sewing-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a perception, Margaret rightly or wrongly, that we are now completely out of touch with the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patronizing tone inflames her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. (beat) How much is a pack of Lurpak?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lurpak?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butter, Francis. (silence) Forty two pence. Anchor butter is forty pence. Flora margarine, still the cheapest, is thirty eight pence. I can assure you I am not out of touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another MINISTER - GILMOUR - whispers the words: "Grocer's Daughter" - as a put down. The men smirk. MARGARET has caught the moment. A sudden flash of the pretty girls in the Grantham Street long ago, laughing at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What - did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GILMOUR makes a gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Nothing, Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET is furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try to hide you opinions. Goodness me, I'd much rather you were honest and straightforward about them - instead of continuously and damagingly leaking them to the press. Well?

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTARILY SILENT-
dialogues.text: MARGARET's eyes travel around the room in waiting-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, people can't pay their mortgages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manufacturing industry is practically on its knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honest, hard-working, decent people are losing their homes. It's terribly shameful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is, Prime Minister, that we must moderate the pace -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - if we're even to have a hope of winning the next election-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Worried about our careers, are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They make noises - to the effect that nothing could be further from the truth. But MARGARET has their measure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, if we don't cut spending we will be bankrupt. Yes the medicine is harsh but the patient requires it in order to live. Shall we withhold the medicine? No! We are not wrong. We did not seek election and win in order to manage the decline of a great nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people of this country chose us because they believe we can restore the health of the British economy and we will do just that! Barring a failure of nerve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SNAP OF COTTON - MARGARET looks at them in a cold fury...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: SILENCE-
dialogues.text: MARGARET nods to the seamstress, dismissing her-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. You saved the day once again, Crawfie, you're an angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET straightens her cuff, testing the button, as the meeting slowly disbands and the MINISTERS move away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't close down a discussion because it's not what you wish to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't expect everyone just to sit there and agree with me. But what kind of leader am I if I don't try to get my own way - to do what I know to be right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But Margaret, one must be careful of testing one's colleagues' loyalty too far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET glances up watching the MINISTERS disappearing, in whispered conversation, like conspirators. (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) Rioting in Brixton, burning cars, huge civil unrest -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are now one split nation, with a huge gulf dividing the employed from the unemployed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) Protest marches, `People's March for Jobs', `No pit closures" -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Thatcher plan is to break the Trade Union movement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be closures of uneconomic coal mines, we seek only an efficient industry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) violent clashes between protesting miners and police -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The miners are being starved back to work, the need is desperate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sweeping along an endless corridor, surrounded by her cabinet, hard on her heels. HOWE, HESELTINE, PYM, PRIOR and OTHERS. MARGARET talking, they hang on her every word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are those who would say hold back, there are those who would make us retreat -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret mid speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we shall never give in to them. We shall never waver, not for a second, in our determination to see this country prosper once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party faithful erupt in cheers, seconded by all Margaret's courtiers on the platform. PYM, PRIOR, HESELTINE, HOWE and above all DENIS, applauding as if their lives depended on it. INT. LADIES. HOUSE OF COMMONS. 1980. DAY. MARGARET sits clutching the sink, a light sweat breaking across her forehead. She looks up-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car bomb has exploded outside Harrods department store, killing six people and injuring 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven soldiers died today when two bombs were detonated during military parades in Hyde Park and Regent's Park. Seven horses also died in the blasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) bombed buildings, horses lying dead in the street, an IRA banner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The IRA have claimed responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET lost in restless sleep- INTERCUT (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) IRA graffiti scrawled on a wall, paramilitaries fire guns, sirens wail. INT. CONFERENCE CENTRE BRIGHTON. 1980. Margaret on the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, it must be business as usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS in pyjamas, brushes his teeth in the bathroom. He glances at MARGARET through the open door as she sits, still in evening dress, working on her speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on love, get to bed. I don't know why you do this to yourself every year, it's a speech at conference, not the Magna Carta!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up, distracted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to call it a day, darling. It's ten to three, for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I'm coming DT. Nearly there -

dialogues.speaker: BOOM
dialogues.text: An almighty explosion rips through the room; wood, glass, furniture splinters, curtains flay from the walls. The fall of plaster, devastating, the hotel room obliterated, reduced to a smoking, dusty rubble. MARGARET stands ghostlike, covered in debris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Denis!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET searching through the haze of fallen plaster, covered with dust, slowly clearing to reveal-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more desperate) Denis- there you are. Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS ghostlike, covered in dust, still in his pyjamas, holding up an obliterated pair of shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My shoes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond, the wall of the bathroom entirely blown away - The CAW of gulls- EXT. GRAND HOTEL. BRIGHTON. 1984. NIGHT. Chaos outside the Grand Hotel in the aftermath of the bomb. The WHIR of SIRENS- DENIS and MARGARET sit in their car, looking out in silent shock at the devastated Grand hotel, reflected on the glass of the car windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's when I thought I'd lost you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET wakes with a start, confused and fumbles for the telephone by her bed-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up phone) Mark?... Hello darling... No, I'm fine... I'm very well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET squints, fingers fumbling for DENIS' watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is... How's... Sarah?... And the children..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sits up -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Oh... You can't... That's a pity... I was hoping to see you... No really darling... That's fine... Of course... another time... Lovely Darling... Can't wait...Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET suddenly relents, a flicker of sudden and urgent need, caught in her eyes-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Mark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence- MARK gone. MARGARET hangs up, stares at- I Whistle A Happy Tune from the King and I just audible- INT. DRAWING ROOM.CHESTER SQUARE.PRESENT.NIGHT. MARGARET stands in the doorway, a jaunty "I Whistle A Happy Tune" seeping from the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was Mark. Not able to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in) Boy's always going AWOL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it costs him a great deal to fly everyone up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you go, making excuses for him. Now look where it's got you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS stands dressed in dinner jacket and bow tie as he reads the back of "The King and I" DVD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know Yul Brynner was a gypsy from Vladivostok?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He moved to Paris when he was fourteen. He played the King of Siam 4,625 times on the London and Broadway stages. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning round shaking a cocktail) One likes to make an effort. A snifter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dead, Denis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Well, if I'm dead... who are you talking to? Shall we dance ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Margaret in his arms. The music changes to `Shall we Dance' from `The King and I' as DENIS takes a confused MARGARET in his arms and begins an expansive waltz round the room. The room turns. YOUNG DENIS dancing with the YOUNG MARGARET. Now its OLD DENIS dancing with OLD MARGARET again. DENIS loses his footing, and MARGARET lurches towards the desk where her eyes fall on figurines of Falklands soldiers. She stares hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Falkland islands, the British Colony in the South Atlantic, has fallen. Argentina claims its marines went ashore this morning as a spearhead to capture key targets, including the capital, Port Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sits, composed, staring up at a phalanx of military men and her ministers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, the Argentinian Junta - which is a fascist gang - has invaded our sovereign territory. This cannot be tolerated. May I make plain my negotiating position. I will not negotiate with criminals or thugs. The Falkland islands belong to Britain, and I want them back. Gentlemen, I need you to tell me today if that is possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possible... just, Prime Minister. We can have a Task Force ready to sail in forty-eight hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET is visibly stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-eight hours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a very narrow weather window. We can't fight in winter down there. Nobody can. If we are going, we have to go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET at her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why were the islands left without any naval protection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the last round of Defence cuts we judged the risk of invasion to be small.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you remember, Prime Minister, you agreed that we should reduce the naval presence in the area to an absolute minimum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET taps her fingers against the map, with growing irritation. INT. CABINET. DOWNING STREET. DAY. MARGARET sits alone. INT CORRIDOR. . CORRIDOR. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1982.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET is under attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, the cost of sending 28,000 men and a hundred ships twelve thousand miles, almost to Argentina, will be absolutely crippling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we should be worrying about money at this point, Geoffrey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't afford to go to war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sits alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The government has now decided that a large task force will sail, as soon as all preparations are complete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) the Task Force sets sail.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING ROOM. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1982. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET paces, deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prime Minister we do still have three weeks before our ships reach the islands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we're saying is that we shouldn't give up on trying to find a diplomatic solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tea trolley and an American entourage surge down a Downing Street corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The U.S. Secretary of State has arrived, Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING ROOM. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1982. DAY
dialogues.text: Haig and Margaret sit facing each other, flanked by senior ministers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you are proposing to go to war over these Islands. They're thousands of miles away, a handful of citizens, politically and economically... insignificant, if you'll excuse me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like Hawaii, I imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1941, when Japan attacked Pearl Harbour. Did America go cap in hand and ask Tojo for a peaceful negotiation of terms? Did she turn her back on her own citizens there because the islands were thousands of miles from mainland United States? No, no, no! We will stand on principle or we shall not stand at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Margaret with all due respect when one has been to war....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect sir, I have done battle every single day of my life, and many men have underestimated me before. This lot seem bound to do the same but they will rue the day.

dialogues.speaker: BEAT
dialogues.text: MARGARET turns to a tea trolley close by-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, shall I be mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAGUE looks confused, MARGARET lifting the teapot-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea, Al, how do you take your tea? Black or white?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NAVAL MEN murmuring messages quietly to NAVAL ATTACHES. Male lips to male ears, something MARGARET has seen all her life. FRANCIS PYM and JOHN NOTT stand near MARGARET. INTERCUT (STOCK FOOTAGE) the naval fleet sails towards the Falklands. A map of South Georgia and the Falkland Islands. Model boats sit on the water, flags sit on the islands. Argentinian flags. MARGARET stares at the map. A whispered message to one of the ATTACHES. He moves a model boat on the map a few inches, leading a fleet of smaller model boats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Argentinian ship the General Belgrano and her escorts are pursuing course 273 degrees toward the Argentinian mainland. We are tracking it with our submarine HMS Conqueror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to a model submarine at some distance from the Argentinian boats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this ship a threat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of these ships are carrying Exocet missiles, Prime Minister. Just yesterday they launched- then aborted- an attack inside the exclusion zone. There is a risk they could try it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Belgrano is sailing directly away from the islands. Can it really be regarded as a threat ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's been changing course continually. There's a strong possibility that they're attempting a pincer movement on our carrier group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I advise that we engage them: hit the Belgrano as a warning to the others. Send them all back to port.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET turns to JOHN NOTT and FRANCIS PYM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll play badly internationally. We'll be seen as aggressors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at the map once more. One of the men supervising the map moves the model of the Belgrano a fraction further North.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will be an escalation, Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks to LEACH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there is to be an escalation, it's better that we start it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is steaming away, Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is staring at MARGARET. Even the ASSISTANTS bustling in the background have stopped and are listening. Male faces turned to her. She herself seems caught in a pincer movement between the politicians and the servicemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sink it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOWNING STREET. 1982. NIGHT
dialogues.text: TV Footage A flash of a torpedo cutting through the water. A thunderous explosion. Flashes of television images- striated and blurry- the Belgrano listing in the water. Reports of the sinking read out by the MOD's Announcer. INT. DRAWING ROOM.CHESTER SQUARE.PRESENT.NIGHT. MARGARET and the Falklands figurine, silhouetted against the dawn light.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOWNING STREET. 1982. NIGHT
dialogues.text: TV Footage CLOSE now - we see a man on fire, burning. VOICES mixing in and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... HMS Sheffield, a Type 42 destroyer, was attacked and hit late this afternoon by an Argentine missile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it is seen as a retaliation for the sinking of the General Belgrano, in which over 300 Argentinian sailors died...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET'S eyes shining, as if with tears. A soft knocking at the door. She dabs them away quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prime Minister -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN NOTT enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latest casualty figures from the Sheffield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) I must write to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prime Minister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The families. I must write to them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET at her desk, looks up at Pym.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foreign Secretary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just been briefed by Admiral Fieldhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me bluntly that if the Argentinians are prepared and willing to risk their aircraft, they have enough missiles to cripple most of our fleet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President Reagan and President Bellaunde of Peru have some new proposals for the peace plan -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) The peace plan? There will be no appeasement. This is a war. A war they started and by God, we will finish. Shall I tell you what I'm going to write to every single one of these families, these heartbroken families? I am going to tell them that no British soldier will die in vain for the Falklands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT (STOCK FOOTAGE) muddy mass graves as the Falklands dead are buried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Colonel Jones. Captain Wood. Captain Dench. Lieutenant Farlaine. Corporal Hardman. Corporal Sullivan. Corporal Briar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET writes to each of the families.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the only Prime Minister in the history of our country who is also a mother with a son of my own, I can imagine your agony, and your grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT (STOCK FOOTAGE) troops march through barren landscapes, helicopters hover, a British flag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prime Minister, we have secured the beachhead -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Argentinian troops are demoralized and ill equipped...The paratroops have taken Goose Green...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shortly after dark last night, our forces executed what our Commander in Chief has called a brilliant surprise night attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sits at a desk in Downing Street, listening to the news reports. A hand turns off the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatcher, bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads down the hall, MARGARET following behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From their new positions, our forces can see large numbers of Argentine soldiers retreating and streaming back into Port Stanley. Our forces are moving forward to exploit their success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) Victory! The Union Jack is raised over Port Stanley. The task force return to England to scenes of jubilation. Embraces, balloons, joyful embraces. INT. CAR. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1982. DUSK. MARGARET peering out, a sea of union jacks and bunting. Cheers, the street lined as the car pulls into Downing Street- The blur of noise, cheering, jostling banners THEN the shroud of black uniforms suddenly encasing the car, blocking out the light- The jaunty distant sound of a military band playing-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well done, M.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car door swings open- A CACOPHONY of CHEERS, APPLAUSE, just audible far off, as MARGARET steps out into the street, the CAMERA follows her out peering up at- DOWNING STREET STAFF leaning out of No 10 windows, waving flags and cheering- MARGARET's gaze lingering on HOWE and PYM amongst them, smiling with congratulations, clearly now part of the victory celebrations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We congratulate the men and women of the armed Forces for their skill, bravery and loyalty to this country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prime Minister's Questions. MARGARET is at the Dispatch Box fighting it out with MICHAEL FOOT. GEOFFREY HOWE IS BESIDE HER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were faced with an act of unprovoked aggression and we responded as we have responded in times past: with unity, strength and courage, sure in the knowledge that though much is sacrificed, in the end, right will prevail over wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge cheers and "hear hears" from the Conservative benches. MICHAEL FOOT shifts uncomfortably on the benches opposite. She is unstoppable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I put it to the Honourable Member opposite that this is not a day for him to carp, find fault, demand inquiries- they will happen I can assure him of that for we have nothing to hide- no, this is a day to put difference aside, hold one's head high and take pride in being British.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnstorming cheers. We see MICHAEL FOOT, utterly outmaneuvered by her speech. The Labour benches sit silent.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON PRESENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: DENIS springs in the air wearing a paper union jack hat, blowing a party hooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GOTCHA! Well that paid off old girl! Your ratings soared! From the most hated Prime Minister of all time to the nation's darling...The world was at your feet, and Britain was back in business!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICKFLASH: A glittering ballroom- MARGARET waltzing, caught in REAGAN's arms, fleetingly passing- DENIS looking on, from the sidelines, drink in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET'S motorcade streaks through the rainy street, Union Jack flying. MARGARET shakes hands with Indira Ghandi. Denis is presented with the pink turban. Newspaper headlines scream PROFITS, PROFITS, PROFITS! MARGARET, triumphant on the podium at party conference. MARGARET shakes hands with Gorbachev. The Berlin Wall comes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Berlin Wall has fallen. The gates have opened! The police are making no attempt to stop people as they go through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headlines: BOOMING BUSINESS! MAGGIE'S MILLIONAIRES!

dialogues.speaker: INT. EMBASSY BALLROOM. 1979. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MARGARET dancing with KENNETH KAUNDA of ZAMBIA, DENIS stands on the touchlines toasting them - a fruity cocktail in his hand. INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS STAIRWAY, 1990. DAY. MARGARET hurries down the stairs, her cabinet in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't agree in any measure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Prime Minister the question of the European single currency will come up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think the country is ready for it yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we cannot bury our heads in the sand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of Conservative MP's and Ministers are saying -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A journalist stands outside the Commons making his report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - that there must be a change in that style of management. That Mrs Thatcher must listen more, and on occasion, give in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET moving swiftly down the hall, leaving her cabinet in her wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is, Prime Minister, I don't think we can sell the idea of a tax that asks everyone to pay the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our policies may be unpopular, but they are the right policies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prime Minister I just don't think we can ask the poorest of the poor to pay the same amount of tax as a multi-millionaire.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CABINET ROOM. DOWNING STREET. 1990. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET, seated at the wide cabinet table surrounded by a subdued CABINET. Most of the familiar old faces - PYM, HESELTINE, etc. All now gone. HOWE the last enduring minister. She casts a gimlet-eye over the GREY-SUITED MEN around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it is again! Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because people... on the whole... think that the tax is manifestly unfair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. Arrant nonsense. This is a simple proposition. In order to live in this country, you must pay for the privilege- something, anything! If you pay nothing, you care nothing. What do you care where you throw your rubbish? Your council estate is a mess, your town, graffiti, what do you care? It's not your problem , it's somebody else's problem- it's the government's problem! YOUR problem is, some of you, is that you haven't got the courage for this fight. You haven't had to fight hard for anything. It's all been given to you- and you feel guilty about it! Well, may I say, on behalf of all those who HAVE had to fight their way up, (and who don't feel guilty about it) we resent those slackers who take, take, take, and contribute nothing to the community!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I see the same thing, the same cowardice in our fight within the European Union, to retain British sovereignty of Britain, the integrity of the pound! Some of you want to make concessions. I hear some of you agree with the latest French proposals. (beat) Well, why don't you get on a boat to Calais? Yes, why don't you put on a beret, and pay 85% of your income to the French government!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has subdued them utterly. The silence is terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. What can we realistically hope to achieve by the end of session, Lord President?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why have we not made more progress to date? What is that? Is that the timetable? I haven't seen that. May I see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it is, Prime Minister. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOWE pushes the papers over to her. She picks up a pencil, starts to read. The MINISTERS watch as, quickly, she starts to score through the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wording is sloppy here, and here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you say so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do say so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's merely a first draft...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET looks down at the paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. There are two "T's" in "committee"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She presses so hard that her pencil breaks, so she shoves the paper back towards him, stabbing a finger at the offending word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is shameful. Shameful! I can't even rely on you for a simple timetable! Are you unwell? Yes you are unwell. Give me the pencil, give it to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET snaps her fingers at HOWE, gesturing for his pencil, scratching away, ringing the offending word again and again. The MINISTERS stare at the scene appalled, utterly and wretchedly embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this is the best you can do I had better send you to hospital, and I shall do your job as well as my own and everyone else's. Gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Lord President has come to cabinet unprepared, I am obliged to close this meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waits for them to take their leave, but they sit there, frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, the men gather their papers and file out of the room, leaving MARGARET alone. She sits, gathering herself, hands shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEAD, grimacing with one eyeball blinded and the other detached and hanging bloody on a cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chanting) Can't pay, won't pay! Can't pay, won't pay! Can't pay, won't pay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET peering out- ANGRY PROTESTORS slapping the glass as they pass, the sense of the car being attacked. The smear of smashed egg against the window screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out... Out... Out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sinks back into her seat as the car, is jostled either side by a blur of colour, the bang of fists against glass, the roar of the crowd -

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRAFALGAR SQUARE. LONDON. 1990. DAY
dialogues.text: (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) Relentless images of violence over this. Mass riots. PROTESTORS charging POLICE LINES. POLICE on HORSEBACK trying to force the PROTESTORS back. One of them - a GIRL - caught out, goes down with her placard, is trampled beneath the horses' hooves, horribly. RIOTERS with blood streaming down their faces. Banners - DEATH TO MAGGIE. OFF WITH HER HEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie... Maggie... Maggie. Out... out... out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a WHOOSH of flames the north side of Piccadilly Circus goes up in flames. Smoke and blood and fire everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OFFICE DOWNING STREET. 1990. DAY
dialogues.text: Late afternoon- MARGARET sits, silently working. HOWE enters, MARGARET barely looks up from working-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoffrey-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My letter of resignation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOWE slides a letter down on her desk- MARGARET looks down at the thick envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our differences, I'm afraid, cannot be reconciled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET resumes working- HOWE waits and waits and waits- The SCRATCH of MARGARET's pen, she works on, refusing to stop for him. INT. CHAMBERS. HOUSE OF COMMONS. LONDON. Howe stands in Parliament, reading his resignation speech:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have done what I believe to be right for my party and my country. The time has come for others to consider their own response to the tragic conflict of loyalties with which I have myself wrestled for perhaps too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET walks alone down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoffrey's speech in the House of Commons was devastating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - just couldn't take any more of the bullying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET's POV as she moves along the corridors of power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was almost inviting someone to challenge her for leadership of the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fellow CABINET MINISTERS, unfamiliar backbenchers, the men in suits, all seem to avoid her gaze...then PYM in conversation with HOWE, abruptly terminated, as both men acknowledge her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She behaved appallingly. I wouldn't have spoken to my gamekeeper like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think she can survive this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET stands, watching the evening news, HESELTINE just visible on the TV screen-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here to announce my decision to put my name forward as leader of the Conservative party. I have nothing but admiration for our Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, but I believe our party and our country need a new leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET turns to DENIS, who stands, clearly shocked, worst fears confirmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's extraordinary. The rules of the Conservative Party make it possible for Conservative MP's to depose a sitting Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET and DENIS on the sofa. She unwraps a sweet, eyes locked on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning to Denis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offering the packet) Sweetie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (STOCK FOOTAGE) WESTMINSTER in the moonlight -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conservative MP's gather in Westminster to discus who they will back in the leadership contest, the Prime Minister said she would not be diverted from critical international affairs

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARIS STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: With the Eiffel Tower illuminated behind him, Trevor MacDonald makes his report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight in Paris Mrs Thatcher is among thirty four world leaders who came together to celebrate the end of the Cold War and herald the start of a peaceful new age of East/West cooperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A magnificent painted hallway- MARGARET sweeping away from a dining room, regal in evening dress.
PARIS - A news journalist makes his report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a general feeling that Mrs Thatcher is going to win on the first ballot. We're going to put it to bed tomorrow night, is how one of her campaign staff puts it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND HALL. PARIS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MARGARET walks through a grand hall with her fellow PRESIDENTS and PRIME MINSTERS of the world, a lone woman amongst a sea of men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M, I really think you should come home and defend yourself old girl. Heseltine is campaigning ferociously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do think my time is best spent seeing an end to the Cold War, don't you? After all this time they know what I stand for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will she, or will she not, be in the job tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GRAND HALL - a formal dinner, MARGARET flanked by bow- tied Prime Ministers and Heads of State.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, they can't touch you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONDON STREETS - CABINET MINISTERS walking along trying to hide their features from prying eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Thatcher has failed to win enough votes to secure an outright win in the leadership contest and must now decide whether to put her name forward for the second round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mrs Thatcher leaves Paris for London to make a last ditch attempt to pull together support for her leadership, the ship may have sailed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET pushes through the double doors into her dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Treachery!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her cabinet are all around her dining room table. There is no seat for her. She moves round the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will never win another election led by that woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need a leader who listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't about her, it's about the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One must know when to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question is, how does anyone put it to her?

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT.
dialogues.text: Close on a minister's face in the dim light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were to stand, I of course would vote for you Prime Minister -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is at her desk in the PRESENT in Chester Square as one minister after another in interchangeable glasses slide into the chair in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - of course would vote for you Prime Minister but I don't think you can win. The loyalty of my colleagues cannot be counted upon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the people who put me here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The loyalty of my colleagues cannot be counted upon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - it's up to them to tell me when to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET stands, watching the evening news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, you can't let them do this to you. Please, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET looks at DENIS, with quiet surprise, hears the desperation in his voice, the crack-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll destroy you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET looks at DENIS, sees he is near to tears-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw in the towel now, love. Don't let those bastards see you humiliated. You just won't win, darling. Not this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Denis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS, fingers touch hers, she looks at him, sees the tender concern in his eyes. MARGARET smiles, determinedly steely under his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 154                  I am the Prime Minister. On her face as CASTA DIVA breaks through.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET sits alone on the front bench.    A stream of voices from the past -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Order! Order!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Right Honourable gentleman is afraid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a naked strategy of closing some coal mines and then selling off -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They believe in striking, I believe in working!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the woman who's watched ten men on hunger strike starve themselves to death and never flinched!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despicable and cowardly -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynical Falklands war -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More homeowners, more shareholders, more savings -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voices begin to blend into one another, white noise.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOWNING STREET STUDY. 1990. EVENING
dialogues.text: MARGARET sips a whisky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I offer my resignation after eleven and a half extraordinary years -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET descends the stairs like an operatic heroine, her hand gripping the banister of the staircase. Below the Downing St staff waiting to say goodbye. Many are in tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -proud to have left Britain in a much better state than when we took office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She passes the photographs of her predecessors and stops to receive a gift, opening it-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this then? A radio... How useful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves down the receiving line of staff. The floor is carpeted with roses. Men's wet eyes. The door ahead. She is crying. Finally reaching the door, MARGARET stands bracing herself. Denis's hand on her shoulder standing behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady, MT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET nods, bracing herself. A hand on the door handle. As it swings open-

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MARGARET stands staring at herself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The greatest Prime Minister since Churchill deposed by a bunch of spineless pygmies!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All those years of taking the tough decisions, does any of it matter now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all been turned to mush!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS lies on the bed behind her with the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By these fools! These lily-livered pinkos!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These inept placators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good! These vacillators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vacillators! Poll takers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Popularity seekers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So busy taking the pulse of the public!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weak -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling down a rack of Denis's black oxford shoes onto the floor) These...weak...weak...weak...wea.. .weak...Men!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS's clothes are all over the room and the main cupboard is open and empty apart from shoes. There are several bin liners already filled with clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't they know if you take the tough decisions, yes people will hate you today but they'll thank you for generations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or forget you entirely and chuck you out with the rubbish!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET turns away from this thought and opens a last big chest of drawers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seizing shirts and jerseys and putting them on the floor) All I wanted was to make a difference in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you did, love, you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits at the end of her bed and opens a box she has found in Denis's cupboard. There is a programme from `The King and I' and a faded blue rosette from some long forgotten election campaign. A small flyer `Margaret Roberts. Conservative Candidate for Dartford' and some childrens cards "to the world's greatest Daddy love Mark and Carol."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I wanted was for my children to grow up well and be happy - happier than I was certainly. And I wanted you to be happy of course. Were you happy, Denis? Tell me the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no response. MARGARET is momentarily lost in the room. Then, seized by some compulsion, she begins to pull out the rest of his clothes, shoving them into black bags. As shirts and trousers go in, quick flashes of Denis - His youthful face, smiling at her at the opera. Laughing on the beach in Cornwall. At the door of Number 10, smiling at her. Sharing her bed. MARGARET looks up. Denis's suitcase is on the bed. His coat and hat lying beside it. She folds his dressing gown - the one from the bathroom hook - tenderly and puts it on the top of the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denis? Denis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there he is by her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your bag. You're all packed, sorted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks him to the bedroom door and gives him a gentle kiss. DENIS starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing he is walking away in his socks) Denis wait...Where are your shoes? You can't go without shoes! Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS straightens his hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...Steady...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady the buffs -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady...Steady the buffs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS heading out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 154d                 NO...Not yet...Denis. Wait...I said I don't want you to go yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The endless corridor, MARGARET calling after DENIS-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denis...Please...No...Not...Don't. ..NO...I don't...I don't want to be on my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENIS turns back for a moment -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to be fine on your own, love. (beat) You always have been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET calling out as DENIS reaches the window at the very far end of the house and appears to disappear into the white light-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Denis!!

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT.DAWN
dialogues.text: From above we see MARGARET lying dead asleep on the bed on a pile of DENIS' clothes. The bed is surrounded by bulging black bin bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummy-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL looming over Margaret, looking horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, Mum. Are you alright? (opening the curtains) Mummy you should have called for help, silly old sausage. Have you not even been in your bed properly? You've done all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, all sorted. Finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET looks around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes well don't worry about all this. June and I will crack on with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just going to get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Shall I call someone, see if anyone can come over and do your hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET looks at her warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. No, you do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL reacts, surprised but pleased. INT. KITCHEN. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY. MARGARET sit finishing a cup of tea. Hears Carol's bustle in the downstairs hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, I'm off June.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. `Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands, picking up the cup. From behind-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh let me do that, Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET's turns for a moment- It is JUNE. MARGARET shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, dear, I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol said you might go to the House of Lords today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no. I'm not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of hot water running. CHINK of a teacup- MARGARET stands, washing up a tea cup. The SQUEAK of her wet cloth, working on a stubborn tea stain, puncturing the silence. The sound of birdsong and children playing drifts from the street outside. MARGARET sets the cup aside, turns and walks out of the room, and out of sight.
